bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861–65.)
bibl.editor: Surgeon General Joseph K. Barnes, United States Army

taxonomy.bibl: Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion

keywords.term: on special wounds and injuries of the head
wounds and injuries of the head
gunshot fractures of the cranial bones
penetrating gunshot fractures of the skull
balls lodged within the cranial cavity
lodgement of missiles within the skull
conoidal musket ball fractured and slightly depressed cranium

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding, edited and added keyword terms

case text extracted and transformed from larger file
initial checking of OCR text against PDF; encoded

body.p: CASE.—Private Jonathan Wiser, Co. E, 49th Pennsylvania Volunteers, aged 35 years, was wounded at the battle of the Wilderness, May 5th, 1864, by a conoidal musket ball, which fractured and slightly depressed the cranium. He was at first admitted to the hospital of the 1st division, Sixth Corps, and, on May 12th, was sent to the Mount Pleasant Hospital, Washington. The records of the latter hospital state that the ball had not been extracted. On September 24th, he was admitted to the Frederick Hospital, Maryland, where he remained under treatment until June 6th, 1865, when he was discharged from service. The case is reported by Assistant Surgeon C. A. McCall, U. S. A. This patient is not on the pension list.
